paper_title: The Kirkendall effect towards oxynitride nanotubes with improved visible light driven conversion of CO<sub>2</sub> into CH<sub>4</sub>

catalyst.source: Oxynitride photocatalysts are a kind of promising material for solar energy conversion.
catalyst.context: Functional hollow nanomaterials are of great interest due to their unique physical-chemical properties.Oxynitride photocatalysts are a kind of promising material for solar energy conversion.However, nanoscale design of hollow oxynitrides was difficult to achieve due to the thermal instability of oxide precursors at high temperature.Here, single crystal zinc gallium oxynitride nanotubes were successfully synthesized via the Kirkendall effect with ZnO nanorods and Ga 2 O 3 nanosheets as precursors, which can be attributed to the high diffusion rate of ZnO and the high melting point of oxynitride.Enhanced photocatalytic performance in CO 2 reduction was achieved over the as-prepared ZnGaNO nanotubes, due to their higher specific surface area and less recombination of the photogenerated carriers.These results are expected to provide new guidance in the design and preparation of highly efficient nano-scaled oxynitride photocatalysts. Experimental Sample preparationA ZnO nanorod was synthesized using Zn(NO 3 ) 2 6H 2 O and ammonium hydroxide as precursors.Typically, 2.5 g Zn(NO 3 ) 2 6H 2 O and 1.0 g ammonium hydroxide were added into 100 ml deionized water, and kept in a water bath at 90 C for 4 h.The Ga 2 O 3 nanosheet was synthesized by a hydrothermal ion-exchange reaction followed by dehydration heat treatment. Electronic supplementary information (ESI) available: EDX analysis and SEM images of ZGNO-SSR and ZnGaNO nanoflowers.See

catalyst.source: Here, we show that hexagonal ZnGaNO oxynitride nanotubes can be successfully fabricated with hexagonal zinc oxide (ZnO) nanorods as a starting material via the Kirkendall effect by ZnO diffusing into the GaN, exhibiting high performance in the photoreduction of carbon dioxide into methane.
catalyst.context: A ZnO nanorod was synthesized using Zn(NO 3 ) 2 6H 2 O and ammonium hydroxide as precursors.Typically, 2.5 g Zn(NO 3 ) 2 6H 2 O and 1.0 g ammonium hydroxide were added into 100 ml deionized water, and kept in a water bath at 90 C for 4 h. The Ga 2 O 3 nanosheet was synthesized by a hydrothermal ion-exchange reaction followed by dehydration heat treatment. Electronic supplementary information (ESI) available: EDX analysis and SEM images of ZGNO-SSR and ZnGaNO nanoflowers.See Functional materials with hollow nanostructures have raised considerable attention, owing to their unique physical and chemical properties achieving extensive applications in many fields such as gas sensing, 1 optoelectronics, 2 field emission, 3 drug delivery, 4,5 luminescence, 6,7 and photocatalysis. 8,9Many methods have been developed for the synthesis of hollow nanostructures, such as use of sacrificial templates, 10 anodization, 11,12 self-organization 13,14 and the Kirkendall effect. 15,168192021 A popular route to the synthesis of oxynitrides is to directly nitride the corresponding oxide precursors at high temperatures (800-1000 C). 22,23This means that it is difficult to achieve the nanoscale design of oxynitride catalysts due to the thermal instability of oxide precursors at high temperature.Recently, we have developed a molten salt ion-exchange method to prepare ZnGaNO nanorods, which exhibited improved performance in CO 2 reduction thanks to the high specific surface area and less crystal defects. 24he Kirkendall effect, a classical phenomenon in metallurgy, has also been found to be an efficient route to obtain the porous materials, where the formation of pores resulted from different diffusion rates between two components in the diffusion couple. 25Hollow nanomaterials synthesized via the Kirkendall effect have been achieved in binary and ternary materials, such as ZnO hollow nanoparticles, 26 ZnS hollow nanospheres, 27 and ZnAl 2 O 4 crystalline nanotubes. 15It was found that ZnO is an excellent core material in forming voids due to its relatively high diffusion rate.Here, we show that hexagonal ZnGaNO oxynitride nanotubes can be successfully fabricated with hexagonal zinc oxide (ZnO) nanorods as a starting material via the Kirkendall effect by ZnO diffusing into the GaN, exhibiting high performance in the photoreduction of carbon dioxide into methane. First, 1.3821 g K 2 CO 3 and 1.8744 g commercial Ga 2 O 3 were evenly mixed, and calcined at 900 C for 16 h to obtain pure KGaO 2 .Then, 1.1264 g KGaO 2 was added into 150 ml water to obtain a clear solution, followed by adding 0.48 g acetic acid slowly.And the solution was stirred under ambient conditions for half an hour, and then kept in a water bath at 80 C for 3 h to obtain GaOOH.Then, the as-prepared GaOOH was calcined at 800 C for 2 h with 50 sccm oxygen flow to obtain -Ga 2 O 3 nanosheet. The ZnGaNO nanotube was synthesized by nitriding a mixture of the as-prepared ZnO nanorod and Ga 2 O 3 nanosheet at 800 C for 5 h at 500 sccm NH 3 flow, followed by loading 0.5 wt Pt as a cocatalyst by the impregnation method. The ZnGaNO-SSR was synthesized by nitriding a mixture of ZnO and Ga 2 O 3 at 850 C for 15 h, followed by loading 0.5 wt Pt as a cocatalyst by the impregnation method. The crystal phase of the derived sample was determined by using an X-ray diffractometer (XRD, Rigaku Ultima III, Japan) operated at 20 kV and 40 mA with Cu-K radiation.Diffuse reflectance spectrum was scanned by using a UV-vis spectrophotometer (UV-2500, Shimadzu Co., Japan) and transformed into an absorption spectrum with the Kubelka-Munk relationship.The specific surface area was measured on nitrogen adsorption at -196 C by using an automatic surface area analyzer (Micromeritics Tristar-3000, USA) after the samples had been dehydrated in N 2 flow at 150 C for 3 h.The surface morphology was characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, FEI Nova Nano SEM 230, USA).TEM images and selected area electron diffraction patterns (SAED) were obtained by employing a transmission electron microscope (TEM, FEI Tecnai G2 F30 S-Twin, USA) operated at 200 kV.The transmission infrared spectra were recorded by Infrared Spectroscopy (FT-IR spectrometer, NEXUS870, Nicolet, USA) under ambient conditions. The photocatalytic CO 2 reaction was carried out in a glass reactor with an area of 4.2 cm 2 .The light source was a 300 W xenon arc lamp from PerfectLight Company, and to obtain visible irradiation, a 420 nm filter was employed.The volume of the reaction chamber was about 230 ml.Before the reaction, the chamber was evacuated several times and then high purity CO 2 gas was introduced into the reaction chamber to achieve ambient pressure.0.4 ml deionized water was injected into the chamber as the reactant.During the reaction, 1 ml gas was extracted from the chamber by using a sampling needle at given intervals for subsequent CH 4 concentration analysis with gas chromatography (GC-2014, Shimadzu Corp., Japan).

catalyst.source: The enhanced photocatalytic performance in CO 2 reduction was achieved over the as-prepared ZnGaNO nanotubes due to their higher specific surface area and less recombination of photogenerated carriers.
catalyst.context: In summary, we demonstrated that the quaternary oxynitride ZnGaNO nanotubes can be successfully fabricated by the Kirkendall effect.The enhanced photocatalytic performance in CO 2 reduction was achieved over the as-prepared ZnGaNO nanotubes due to their higher specific surface area and less recombination of photogenerated carriers.The new synthetic strategy may provide a new guidance for the design and preparation of efficient nano-scaled oxynitride photocatalysts. Fig. 1 (a) XRD patterns of precursors Ga 2 O 3 , ZnO ZnGaNO and GaN (JCPDS card no.76-0703).(b) UV-Vis absorption spectrum of the asprepared ZnGaNO solid solution. Fig. 2 SEM images of ZnO nanorods (a), Ga 2 O 3 nanoplates (b), ZnGaNO nanotubes (c) and cross section of ZnGaNO nanotubes (d), TEM image of ZnGaNO nanotubes (e), SAED patterns of ZnGaNO nanotubes. Fig.3The schematic graph shows the forming process of ZnGaNO nanotube via the Kirkendall effect.Fig. 4 SEM images of ZnO rods (a) and ZnGaNO tubes (b). Fig. 5 The time course evolution of methane yields by CO 2 photoreduction under visible light irradiation over ZGNO-nanotube, ZGNO-SSR, ZGNO-tube and ZGNO-nanorod (a) and a comparison of full-arc and visible light irradiation over ZGNO-nanotube (b). Fig.6The band structures of ZGNO-SSR, ZGNO-tube, ZGNO-nanotube and ZGNO-nanorod at pH 7. This journal is The Royal Society of Chemistry 2016 Published on 11 January 2016.Downloaded by RMIT Uni on 23/02/2016 11:23:07.View Article Online This work was supported primarily by the National Basic Research Program of China (2013CB632404), the State Key Laboratory of NBC Protection for Civilian (No. SKLNBC2014-09), the Natural Science Foundation of Jiangsu Province (BK20151265), and the National Natural Science Foundation of China (51572121).

co-catalyst.source: The ZnGaNO nanotube was synthesized by nitriding a mixture of the as-prepared ZnO nanorod and Ga 2 O 3 nanosheet at 800 C for 5 h at 500 sccm NH 3 flow, followed by loading 0.5 wt Pt as a cocatalyst by the impregnation method.
co-catalyst.context: A ZnO nanorod was synthesized using Zn(NO 3 ) 2 6H 2 O and ammonium hydroxide as precursors.Typically, 2.5 g Zn(NO 3 ) 2 6H 2 O and 1.0 g ammonium hydroxide were added into 100 ml deionized water, and kept in a water bath at 90 C for 4 h. The Ga 2 O 3 nanosheet was synthesized by a hydrothermal ion-exchange reaction followed by dehydration heat treatment. Electronic supplementary information (ESI) available: EDX analysis and SEM images of ZGNO-SSR and ZnGaNO nanoflowers.See Functional materials with hollow nanostructures have raised considerable attention, owing to their unique physical and chemical properties achieving extensive applications in many fields such as gas sensing, 1 optoelectronics, 2 field emission, 3 drug delivery, 4,5 luminescence, 6,7 and photocatalysis. 8,9Many methods have been developed for the synthesis of hollow nanostructures, such as use of sacrificial templates, 10 anodization, 11,12 self-organization 13,14 and the Kirkendall effect. 15,168192021 A popular route to the synthesis of oxynitrides is to directly nitride the corresponding oxide precursors at high temperatures (800-1000 C). 22,23This means that it is difficult to achieve the nanoscale design of oxynitride catalysts due to the thermal instability of oxide precursors at high temperature.Recently, we have developed a molten salt ion-exchange method to prepare ZnGaNO nanorods, which exhibited improved performance in CO 2 reduction thanks to the high specific surface area and less crystal defects. 24he Kirkendall effect, a classical phenomenon in metallurgy, has also been found to be an efficient route to obtain the porous materials, where the formation of pores resulted from different diffusion rates between two components in the diffusion couple. 25Hollow nanomaterials synthesized via the Kirkendall effect have been achieved in binary and ternary materials, such as ZnO hollow nanoparticles, 26 ZnS hollow nanospheres, 27 and ZnAl 2 O 4 crystalline nanotubes. 15It was found that ZnO is an excellent core material in forming voids due to its relatively high diffusion rate.Here, we show that hexagonal ZnGaNO oxynitride nanotubes can be successfully fabricated with hexagonal zinc oxide (ZnO) nanorods as a starting material via the Kirkendall effect by ZnO diffusing into the GaN, exhibiting high performance in the photoreduction of carbon dioxide into methane. First, 1.3821 g K 2 CO 3 and 1.8744 g commercial Ga 2 O 3 were evenly mixed, and calcined at 900 C for 16 h to obtain pure KGaO 2 .Then, 1.1264 g KGaO 2 was added into 150 ml water to obtain a clear solution, followed by adding 0.48 g acetic acid slowly.And the solution was stirred under ambient conditions for half an hour, and then kept in a water bath at 80 C for 3 h to obtain GaOOH.Then, the as-prepared GaOOH was calcined at 800 C for 2 h with 50 sccm oxygen flow to obtain -Ga 2 O 3 nanosheet. The ZnGaNO nanotube was synthesized by nitriding a mixture of the as-prepared ZnO nanorod and Ga 2 O 3 nanosheet at 800 C for 5 h at 500 sccm NH 3 flow, followed by loading 0.5 wt Pt as a cocatalyst by the impregnation method. The ZnGaNO-SSR was synthesized by nitriding a mixture of ZnO and Ga 2 O 3 at 850 C for 15 h, followed by loading 0.5 wt Pt as a cocatalyst by the impregnation method. The crystal phase of the derived sample was determined by using an X-ray diffractometer (XRD, Rigaku Ultima III, Japan) operated at 20 kV and 40 mA with Cu-K radiation.Diffuse reflectance spectrum was scanned by using a UV-vis spectrophotometer (UV-2500, Shimadzu Co., Japan) and transformed into an absorption spectrum with the Kubelka-Munk relationship.The specific surface area was measured on nitrogen adsorption at -196 C by using an automatic surface area analyzer (Micromeritics Tristar-3000, USA) after the samples had been dehydrated in N 2 flow at 150 C for 3 h.The surface morphology was characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, FEI Nova Nano SEM 230, USA).TEM images and selected area electron diffraction patterns (SAED) were obtained by employing a transmission electron microscope (TEM, FEI Tecnai G2 F30 S-Twin, USA) operated at 200 kV.The transmission infrared spectra were recorded by Infrared Spectroscopy (FT-IR spectrometer, NEXUS870, Nicolet, USA) under ambient conditions. The photocatalytic CO 2 reaction was carried out in a glass reactor with an area of 4.2 cm 2 .The light source was a 300 W xenon arc lamp from PerfectLight Company, and to obtain visible irradiation, a 420 nm filter was employed.The volume of the reaction chamber was about 230 ml.Before the reaction, the chamber was evacuated several times and then high purity CO 2 gas was introduced into the reaction chamber to achieve ambient pressure.0.4 ml deionized water was injected into the chamber as the reactant.During the reaction, 1 ml gas was extracted from the chamber by using a sampling needle at given intervals for subsequent CH 4 concentration analysis with gas chromatography (GC-2014, Shimadzu Corp., Japan).

performance in the photoreduction of carbon dioxide into methane. The crystal phase of the derived sample was determined by using an X-ray diffractometer (XRD, Rigaku Ultima III, Japan) operated at 20 kV and 40 mA with Cu-K radiation.Diffuse reflectance spectrum was scanned by using a UV-vis spectrophotometer (UV-2500, Shimadzu Co., Japan) and transformed into an absorption spectrum with the Kubelka-Munk relationship.The specific surface area was measured on nitrogen adsorption at -196 C by using an automatic surface area analyzer (Micromeritics Tristar-3000, USA) after the samples had been dehydrated in N 2 flow at 150 C for 3 h.The surface morphology was characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, FEI Nova Nano SEM 230, USA).TEM images and selected area electron diffraction patterns (SAED) were obtained by employing a transmission electron microscope (TEM, FEI Tecnai G2 F30 S-Twin, USA) operated at 200 kV.The transmission infrared spectra were recorded by Infrared Spectroscopy (FT-IR spectrometer, NEXUS870, Nicolet, USA) under ambient conditions. lamp.source: The light source was a 300 W xenon arc lamp from PerfectLight Company, and to obtain visible irradiation, a 420 nm filter was employed.
lamp.context: A ZnO nanorod was synthesized using Zn(NO 3 ) 2 6H 2 O and ammonium hydroxide as precursors.Typically, 2.5 g Zn(NO 3 ) 2 6H 2 O and 1.0 g ammonium hydroxide were added into 100 ml deionized water, and kept in a water bath at 90 C for 4 h. The Ga 2 O 3 nanosheet was synthesized by a hydrothermal ion-exchange reaction followed by dehydration heat treatment. Electronic supplementary information (ESI) available: EDX analysis and SEM images of ZGNO-SSR and ZnGaNO nanoflowers.See Functional materials with hollow nanostructures have raised considerable attention, owing to their unique physical and chemical properties achieving extensive applications in many fields such as gas sensing, 1 optoelectronics, 2 field emission, 3 drug delivery, 4,5 luminescence, 6,7 and photocatalysis. 8,9Many methods have been developed for the synthesis of hollow nanostructures, such as use of sacrificial templates, 10 anodization, 11,12 self-organization 13,14 and the Kirkendall effect. 15,168192021 A popular route to the synthesis of oxynitrides is to directly nitride the corresponding oxide precursors at high temperatures (800-1000 C). 22,23This means that it is difficult to achieve the nanoscale design of oxynitride catalysts due to the thermal instability of oxide precursors at high temperature.Recently, we have developed a molten salt ion-exchange method to prepare ZnGaNO nanorods, which exhibited improved performance in CO 2 reduction thanks to the high specific surface area and less crystal defects. 24he Kirkendall effect, a classical phenomenon in metallurgy, has also been found to be an efficient route to obtain the porous materials, where the formation of pores resulted from different diffusion rates between two components in the diffusion couple. 25Hollow nanomaterials synthesized via the Kirkendall effect have been achieved in binary and ternary materials, such as ZnO hollow nanoparticles, 26 ZnS hollow nanospheres, 27 and ZnAl 2 O 4 crystalline nanotubes. 15It was found that ZnO is an excellent core material in forming voids due to its relatively high diffusion rate.Here, we show that hexagonal ZnGaNO oxynitride nanotubes can be successfully fabricated with hexagonal zinc oxide (ZnO) nanorods as a starting material via the Kirkendall effect by ZnO diffusing into the GaN, exhibiting high performance in the photoreduction of carbon dioxide into methane. First, 1.3821 g K 2 CO 3 and 1.8744 g commercial Ga 2 O 3 were evenly mixed, and calcined at 900 C for 16 h to obtain pure KGaO 2 .Then, 1.1264 g KGaO 2 was added into 150 ml water to obtain a clear solution, followed by adding 0.48 g acetic acid slowly.And the solution was stirred under ambient conditions for half an hour, and then kept in a water bath at 80 C for 3 h to obtain GaOOH.Then, the as-prepared GaOOH was calcined at 800 C for 2 h with 50 sccm oxygen flow to obtain -Ga 2 O 3 nanosheet. The ZnGaNO nanotube was synthesized by nitriding a mixture of the as-prepared ZnO nanorod and Ga 2 O 3 nanosheet at 800 C for 5 h at 500 sccm NH 3 flow, followed by loading 0.5 wt Pt as a cocatalyst by the impregnation method. The ZnGaNO-SSR was synthesized by nitriding a mixture of ZnO and Ga 2 O 3 at 850 C for 15 h, followed by loading 0.5 wt Pt as a cocatalyst by the impregnation method. The crystal phase of the derived sample was determined by using an X-ray diffractometer (XRD, Rigaku Ultima III, Japan) operated at 20 kV and 40 mA with Cu-K radiation.Diffuse reflectance spectrum was scanned by using a UV-vis spectrophotometer (UV-2500, Shimadzu Co., Japan) and transformed into an absorption spectrum with the Kubelka-Munk relationship.The specific surface area was measured on nitrogen adsorption at -196 C by using an automatic surface area analyzer (Micromeritics Tristar-3000, USA) after the samples had been dehydrated in N 2 flow at 150 C for 3 h.The surface morphology was characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, FEI Nova Nano SEM 230, USA).TEM images and selected area electron diffraction patterns (SAED) were obtained by employing a transmission electron microscope (TEM, FEI Tecnai G2 F30 S-Twin, USA) operated at 200 kV.The transmission infrared spectra were recorded by Infrared Spectroscopy (FT-IR spectrometer, NEXUS870, Nicolet, USA) under ambient conditions. The photocatalytic CO 2 reaction was carried out in a glass reactor with an area of 4.2 cm 2 .The light source was a 300 W xenon arc lamp from PerfectLight Company, and to obtain visible irradiation, a 420 nm filter was employed.The volume of the reaction chamber was about 230 ml.Before the reaction, the chamber was evacuated several times and then high purity CO 2 gas was introduced into the reaction chamber to achieve ambient pressure.0.4 ml deionized water was injected into the chamber as the reactant.During the reaction, 1 ml gas was extracted from the chamber by using a sampling needle at given intervals for subsequent CH 4 concentration analysis with gas chromatography (GC-2014, Shimadzu Corp., Japan).

13,14 and the Kirkendall effect. 15,168192021 A popular route to the synthesis of oxynitrides is to directly nitride the corresponding oxide precursors at high temperatures (800-1000 C). 22,23This means that it is difficult to achieve the nanoscale design of oxynitride catalysts due to the thermal instability of oxide precursors at high temperature.Recently, we have developed a molten salt ion-exchange method to prepare ZnGaNO nanorods, which exhibited improved performance in CO 2 reduction thanks to the high specific surface area and less crystal defects. 24he Kirkendall effect, a classical phenomenon in metallurgy, has also been found to be an efficient route to obtain the porous materials, where the formation of pores resulted from different diffusion rates between two components in the diffusion couple. 25Hollow nanomaterials synthesized via the Kirkendall effect have been achieved in binary and ternary materials, such as ZnO hollow nanoparticles, 26 ZnS hollow nanospheres, 27 and ZnAl 2 O 4 crystalline nanotubes. 15It was found that ZnO is an excellent core material in forming voids due to its relatively high diffusion rate.Here, we show that hexagonal ZnGaNO oxynitride nanotubes can be successfully fabricated with hexagonal zinc oxide (ZnO) nanorods as a starting material via the Kirkendall effect by ZnO diffusing into the GaN, exhibiting high performance in the photoreduction of carbon dioxide into methane. First, 1.3821 g K 2 CO 3 and 1.8744 g commercial Ga 2 O 3 were evenly mixed, and calcined at 900 C for 16 h to obtain pure KGaO 2 .Then, 1.1264 g KGaO 2 was added into 150 ml water to obtain a clear solution, followed by adding 0.48 g acetic acid slowly.And the solution was stirred under ambient conditions for half an hour, and then kept in a water bath at 80 C for 3 h to obtain GaOOH.Then, the as-prepared GaOOH was calcined at 800 C for 2 h with 50 sccm oxygen flow to obtain -Ga 2 O 3 nanosheet. The ZnGaNO nanotube was synthesized by nitriding a mixture of the as-prepared ZnO nanorod and Ga 2 O 3 nanosheet at 800 C for 5 h at 500 sccm NH 3 flow, followed by loading 0.5 wt Pt as a cocatalyst by the impregnation method. The ZnGaNO-SSR was synthesized by nitriding a mixture of ZnO and Ga 2 O 3 at 850 C for 15 h, followed by loading 0.5 wt Pt as a cocatalyst by the impregnation method. The crystal phase of the derived sample was determined by using an X-ray diffractometer (XRD, Rigaku Ultima III, Japan) operated at 20 kV and 40 mA with Cu-K radiation.Diffuse reflectance spectrum was scanned by using a UV-vis spectrophotometer (UV-2500, Shimadzu Co., Japan) and transformed into an absorption spectrum with the Kubelka-Munk relationship.The specific surface area was measured on nitrogen adsorption at -196 C by using an automatic surface area analyzer (Micromeritics Tristar-3000, USA) after the samples had been dehydrated in N 2 flow at 150 C for 3 h.The surface morphology was characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, FEI Nova Nano SEM 230, USA).TEM images and selected area electron diffraction patterns (SAED) were obtained by employing a transmission electron microscope (TEM, FEI Tecnai G2 F30 S-Twin, USA) operated at 200 kV.The transmission infrared spectra were recorded by Infrared Spectroscopy (FT-IR spectrometer, NEXUS870, Nicolet, USA) under ambient conditions. The photocatalytic CO 2 reaction was carried out in a glass reactor with an area of 4.2 cm 2 .The light source was a 300 W xenon arc lamp from PerfectLight Company, and to obtain visible irradiation, a 420 nm filter was employed.The volume of the reaction chamber was about 230 ml.Before the reaction, the chamber was evacuated several times and then high purity CO 2 gas was introduced into the reaction chamber to achieve ambient pressure.0.4 ml deionized water was injected into the chamber as the reactant.During the reaction, 1 ml gas was extracted from the chamber by using a sampling needle at given intervals for subsequent CH 4 concentration analysis with gas chromatography (GC-2014, Shimadzu Corp., Japan).

operation mode.source: During the reaction, 1 ml gas was extracted from the chamber by using a sampling needle at given intervals for subsequent CH 4 concentration analysis with gas chromatography (GC-2014, Shimadzu Corp., Japan).
operation mode.context: A ZnO nanorod was synthesized using Zn(NO 3 ) 2 6H 2 O and ammonium hydroxide as precursors.Typically, 2.5 g Zn(NO 3 ) 2 6H 2 O and 1.0 g ammonium hydroxide were added into 100 ml deionized water, and kept in a water bath at 90 C for 4 h. The Ga 2 O 3 nanosheet was synthesized by a hydrothermal ion-exchange reaction followed by dehydration heat treatment. Electronic supplementary information (ESI) available: EDX analysis and SEM images of ZGNO-SSR and ZnGaNO nanoflowers.See Functional materials with hollow nanostructures have raised considerable attention, owing to their unique physical and chemical properties achieving extensive applications in many fields such as gas sensing, 1 optoelectronics, 2 field emission, 3 drug delivery, 4,5 luminescence, 6,7 and photocatalysis. 8,9Many methods have been developed for the synthesis of hollow nanostructures, such as use of sacrificial templates, 10 anodization, 11,12 self-organization 13,14 and the Kirkendall effect. 15,168192021 A popular route to the synthesis of oxynitrides is to directly nitride the corresponding oxide precursors at high temperatures (800-1000 C). 22,23This means that it is difficult to achieve the nanoscale design of oxynitride catalysts due to the thermal instability of oxide precursors at high temperature.Recently, we have developed a molten salt ion-exchange method to prepare ZnGaNO nanorods, which exhibited improved performance in CO 2 reduction thanks to the high specific surface area and less crystal defects. 24he Kirkendall effect, a components in the diffusion couple. 25Hollow nanomaterials synthesized via the Kirkendall effect have been achieved in binary and ternary materials, such as ZnO hollow nanoparticles, 26 ZnS hollow
